dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey B, uh, have you heard about Relativity Space? These guys are doing some wild stuff in, like, the rocket industry.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey B, uh, have you heard about Relativity Space? These guys are doing some wild stuff in, like, the rocket industry.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah! The ones with the, um, 3D-printed rockets? That just sounds wild, like, sci-fi stuff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah! The ones with the, um, 3D-printed rockets? That just sounds wild, like, sci-fi stuff.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally! They're actually examining the second stage of their Terran 1 rocket, which, get this, is *entirely* 3D-printed. And they just landed a huge round of funding.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally! They're actually examining the second stage of their Terran one rocket, which, get this, is entirely 3D-printed. And they just landed a huge round of funding.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Space Relativity founders Tim Ellis and Jordan Noone examine the second stage of their Terran 1 rocket, which was entirely 3D-printed The capital raise will enable the company to fully develop and test its rocket, dubbed Terran 1, and begin commercial operations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, [interrupts] entirely? That's insane. How much did they, uh, raise?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, entirely? That's insane. How much did they, uh, raise?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, they just got another $140 million, which brings their total investment to, like, $185 million. Mark Cuban's even one of their early investors and still involved.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, they just got another one hundred forty million dollars, which brings their total investment to, like, one hundred eighty five million dollars. Mark Cuban's even one of their early investors and still involved.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The $140 million fundraise brings the total amount of investment in the company to $185 million. The Los Angeles-based startup has a lot of believers, including billionaire Mark Cuban, the companys first investor and also a participant in the current round

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: $185 million? That's a serious chunk of change. But, you know, the article mentions this market is, like, super crowded, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: one hundred eighty five million dollars? That's a serious chunk of change. But, you know, the article mentions this market is, like, super crowded, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. There are over a hundred startups trying to build small rockets. But, um, only one of them, Rocket Lab, has actually launched commercial payloads to orbit so far.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. There are over a hundred startups trying to build small rockets. But, um, only one of them, Rocket Lab, has actually launched commercial payloads to orbit so far.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There are over 100 startups now in the race to build small rockets... However, only one of those companiesthe L.A.-based Rocket Labhas launched commercial payloads to orbit.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, so how does Relativity Space, like, stand out then? What's their, uh, secret sauce?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, so how does Relativity Space, like, stand out then? What's their, uh, secret sauce?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, Tim Ellis, their CEO, he says their competitive advantage is their manufacturing process. They're 3D-printing *everything*, from the engine to the structure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, Tim Ellis, their C E O, he says their competitive advantage is their manufacturing process. They're 3D-printing everything, from the engine to the structure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Relativitys Ellis believes that its competitive advantage lies in its manufacturing process. The company is 3D-printing its rockets, from the engine to the structure...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, [interrupts] like, faster production, I guess?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, faster production, I guess?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! They've built these massive 3D printers they call 'Stargate.' Once their factory's fully built, they can produce and iterate rockets really, really quickly. It's, um, a much more automated process.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! They've built these massive 3D printers they call Stargate. Once their factory's fully built, they can produce and iterate rockets really, really quickly. It's, um, a much more automated process.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To that end, the company has built four large 3D-printers, which it calls Stargate, at its manufacturing facility. Once engineering is complete and the factory is fully built, Ellis says, his company will be able to produce and iterate rockets very quickly. ...it is a significantly more automated process, he says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's pretty smart. Do they have, like, any customers lined up already, or are they still just building?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's pretty smart. Do they have, like, any customers lined up already, or are they still just building?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: They do! They've signed deals with Telesat, mu Space, and Spaceflight. Launches are around $10 million, which is, uh, pretty competitive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They do! They've signed deals with Telesat, mu Space, and Spaceflight. Launches are around ten million dollars, which is, uh, pretty competitive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company has signed deals with Canadian communications company Telesat to deliver internet satellites to orbit, with Thai company mu Space, and with Spaceflight... Launches cost $10 million, in the ballpark of current satellite launches.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, so they're not just, like, dreaming; they're actually making it happen. And I saw something about them looking beyond Earth, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, so they're not just, like, dreaming; they're actually making it happen. And I saw something about them looking beyond Earth, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Ellis, um, he's already looking at Mars. Part of their long-term vision is actually 3D-printing rockets and infrastructure *on* Mars someday.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Ellis, um, he's already looking at Mars. Part of their long-term vision is actually 3D-printing rockets and infrastructure on Mars someday.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Part of our long-term vision is one day 3D-printing rockets and infrastructure on Mars, he says.

dialogue_turns.text: On Mars? That's, like, incredibly ambitious. This company is definitely one to watch.
